title: 108_s759
content: The Act titled "Residential, Farm, Ranch, and Small Business Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003" or "Small Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003" introduces a credit for residential small wind energy systems under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act allows a 30% tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures made by individuals. The credit is limited to $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity and requires safety certifications. Any excess credit can be carried forward to future taxable years. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures allows excess credits to be carried forward to future taxable years. Qualified wind energy property expenditure is defined as an expenditure for qualified wind energy property installed on a dwelling unit in the US used as a residence, including installation fees. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures allows excess credits to be carried forward to future taxable years. A qualifying wind turbine must have a 5-year limited warranty and meet performance rating standards. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures includes labor costs for onsite preparation and installation, but excludes costs for energy storage mediums with functions other than storage. Special rules apply for joint occupancy situations. In cases of joint occupancy for a dwelling unit used as a residence by multiple individuals, the tax credit allowable for expenditures made by any individual is determined by treating all individuals as one taxpayer. Each individual is eligible for a credit for their expenditures in the taxable year. Individuals can claim a tax credit for their expenditures in a calendar year based on the ratio of their expenses to the total expenses of all individuals. Tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations are considered to have made their share of the corporation's expenditures. For individuals in condominiums, they can also claim a tax credit for their expenses. Individuals in condominiums who are members of a condominium management association are treated as having made their share of the association's expenses. The term 'condominium management association' refers to an organization meeting specific requirements for a residential condominium project. If less than 80 percent of a qualified wind energy property is used, allocation rules apply. When using a qualified wind energy property for nonbusiness purposes and selling energy to others, only the portion of expenditures allocated to these uses is considered. Expenditures for qualified wind energy property are recognized when the installation is completed and energy generation begins. Expenditures for construction or reconstruction of a structure are treated as made when the taxpayer begins using the structure. The amount of the expenditure is the cost. Expenditures made from subsidized energy financing are not considered for determining the amount spent on a dwelling unit. Basis adjustments are made if a credit is allowed for qualified wind energy property. The basis of qualified wind energy property is reduced by the amount of the credit allowed. The section does not apply to property installed after December 31, 2008. The credit allowed for the taxable year is limited by the sum of regular tax liability and tax imposed by section 55. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property is limited by the sum of regular tax liability and tax imposed by section 55. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code to reflect this limitation. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including inserting section 25C in multiple places and striking section 25B in others to reflect limitations on the tax credit for qualified wind energy property. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include inserting section 25C and striking section 1400C for taxable years before January 1, 2004. Section 25(e)(1)(C) is also amended to include references to section 25C. Additionally, section 1016 is amended to include provisions related to section 25C credits. Section 1400C(d) is amended to reflect changes for taxable years before January 1, 2004. The Internal Revenue Code for years before January 1, 2004, is amended by adding section 25C after "this section." The table of sections is updated to include the new item related to section 25C. The amendments made by section 25C on residential wind energy property apply to expenditures after December 31, 2002, in taxable years ending after that date. The amendments made by subsection (b) apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003. Additionally, a credit is provided for business installation of small wind energy property under section 3. The amendment to section 48 of the Internal Revenue Code defines qualified wind energy property installed before January 1, 2009. Qualified wind energy property is a qualifying wind turbine installed on or in connection with a specific location. Qualified wind energy property must be installed on a farm, ranch, or eligible small business in the US, owned and used by the taxpayer, with the original use starting with the taxpayer, and carrying a 5-year limited warranty. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property is limited to 30% of the property's basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity. A qualifying wind turbine is defined as one with a rated capacity of 75 kilowatts or less. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property is limited to 30% of the property's basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity, with safety certifications required. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property is limited to 30% of the property's basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity, with safety certifications required. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 specify the percentage for different types of energy property and make a conforming amendment. The effective date for these changes is after December 31, 2003.
